Historically, broadly speaking, if you look at what people have done from machine learning community, I would say we've been computational biologists.
We focused on constructing models from the data, but their standard generic type models.

They make certain assumptions, things like common filters, Bayesian networks, linear regression, models, PCA are models very much a data driven approach, so there is very little structural information about what's going on in the networks.
On the other side, systems biologists who typically tend to come from more of a chemical kinetics or physics background.
They focused on analyzing these systems and trying to workout what sort of broad brush stroke behavior they exhibit, and therefore what sort of connections there must be between them.
So one example there Nick Monk, who was at Sheffield, is now, and Nottingham is very well known for forcing the importance of delays in the differential equation models of these systems.
